bibl.title: James Douglas v. Henry M. White. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the Superior Court of the State of Washington for County
Filed in the United States District Court
In the matter of Deportation of James Douglas, a Alien.
To the Hon, Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of the above entitled Court at Seattle, State of Washington:

The petition of James Douglas respectfully shows: That he, the said James Douglas is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confied and restrained of his liberty by Henry M. White, commissioner of immigration, at Seattle, Washington, at the detention station in the City of Seattle, and State of Washington.

That the said imprisonment, detention, confinement, and restraint are illegal; and that the illegality thereof consists in this, to-wit; Your petitioner is an alien and a citizen of the Dominion of Canada; that on or about the 20th. day of March, 1919, the said James Douglas was found in the United States and in the City of Seattle, Washington, and was thereafter charged by the United States department of labor on a warrant, charging that the he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry into the United States; that thereafter and on August 9th. 1919, a hearing on said warrant for his deportation was had before the Hon. Henry M. White, commissioner of immigration at Seattle, Washington, and the evidence adduced at said hearing was thereafter submitted to the United States department of labor, and as a consequence of which, the said department of labor, has issued its order directing that the said James Douglas be deported from the United States to the Dominion of Canada; that the evidence adduced at said hearing and upon which the deportation of labor acted is wholly insificient and does not warrant the deportation of the said James Douglas from the United States; that the said James Douglas is a male citizen physically sound and in good health and has been constantly employed ever since his entry into the United States at good wages, and is not likely to become a public charge; that the said James Douglas did not violate the immigration act of February 5th. 1917, under which act he has been charged, arrested and deported.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prys that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted directed to Hon Henry M White, U.S. cmmsr, commanding him to have the body of James Douglas before your Honor at a time and place to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered by your Honor, concerning the said James Douglas together with the time and cause of his detention, and said writ, and that he, the said James Douglas be restored to his liberty.
State of Washington, County of King,
I, James Douglas, named in the foregoing petition, do hereby make solemn oath that the statements of fact therein contained are true, according to the best of my knowledge, information and belief.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this the 19th. day of December, A.S. 1919.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
